abstract.p: The geometric modeling of free-form curves and surfaces is of a central importance for sophisticated CAD systems. Apart from the pure construction of these curves and surfaces, the analysis of their quality is equally important in fhe design process. In the scope of this article, we will d i s c u s various visualization techniques, which have the goal of identifying unwanted curvature regions (inflection points, dents,. . .) interactively on screen. [8] Th. Schreiber, Contouring Algorithmen. Diplomarbeit TU Emunschweig, (1989)

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The purpose of this paper is to give a critical survey on surface interrogation methods. First we will disc u s several isoline and contouring techniques. Then we will present the reflection line method, which simulates the so-called light cage by computer graphics. The isophote method analyzes surfaces by determining lines of equal light intensity; silhouettes are special isophotes. A different approach to these problems are the mapping-techniques. Here the simulation of natural light effects by computer graphics is not used; the mapping methods recognize unwanted curvature regions by detecting singularities of a special mapping of the curve or surface to investigate. We will have a closer look at the polarity method and the k-orthotomics. Curvature plots are also a practical means of analyzing free-form surfaces. All these methods are effective, but generally need a lot of computational effort. It is therefore desirable to use these methods only for a fine analysis of critical regions. This is possible, if surface patches can be identified, which cannot contain such unwanted curvature regions. The free-form surface visualization by ray tracing is such a technique and will be discussed shortly.

div.head: Generalized Isophote Method
div.p: In very many cases curvature discontinuities of patchworks appear acroes the boundary curves. Here we describe a technique for visualization of such discontinuities [7].

The envelope of the tangent planes along a surfacecurve y is a developable, ruled surface @. At each point p of y, the tangent y is a conjugate to the corresponding ruling of @. Conjugate directions are conjugate diameters of the Dupin indicatrix. Such conjugate directions satisfy the symmetric bilinear equation:

This relation degenerates at parabolic points, because the asymptotic direction (the direction in which the normal section curvature vanishes) is the conjugate to itself, but also conjugate to all other directions. At planar points, we have this degeneration for each (tangent) direction.

Let X' and X 2 denote the two @ surface patches of the patchwork X , G'-continuously linked together along the common boundary curve y. Since both X' and X 2 have y as a surface curve, and the tangent planes along y are unique, the Dupin indicatrices have a common diameter, but in general there are no further common elements.

div.p: A mapping technique places emphasis on undesired curvature regions as singularities of a special mapping of the curve or surface to be investigated (see [3] and t4).

We now want to demonstrate this method with two practical examples. First we will consider a set of Bezier curves. The above shown hair dryer was modeled from a presmoothed net of curves, where by the optimal curvature input at the patch corners was determined by a variational approach. The curvature plot compares the normal section curvature of the surface curve with the normal section curvature, which is obtained by setting the twist vectors to zero ( a standard type of error). For more details see [l]. Another surface interrogation method is the visualization of the Gaussian curvature by color. Using this technique one must be aware of the fact, that one cannot distinguish between parabolic or flat regions on a surface.
